Text:
An interactive playground that illustrates various method to animate things in Tooll.

[Value]

Tooll is all about animation. So there are endless possibilities for it. This playground shows some examples. 
Try to select the operators at the end of each graph and play with them.

(please activate the Idle Motion mode in the time controls)

Using time. Notice that Tooll's time is not in secs but in musical bars -
4 beats is 1 bar. 4 bars form a measure. This means that your animation
will work for all BPM-rates!

Math is your friend (even if you didn't love it in school).
Understanding these 3 functions will be a game changer for your work.
Keep in mind that you can always combine things.

If values fall in the range between 0 and 1, nerds call them "Normalized" or "Saturated".
The Pow function is very useful to add easing to your normalized values.

There are operators that are animated without a connection to [Time]*
These operators are such powerful tools that we should explain them in detail:
* These are automatically connected to time.

Mucians might know [AnimValue] operator as
"LFO" (Low frequency operator).

You can adjust its main parameters directly by holding 
the CTRL key.
- Drag Up/Down on the left adjusts the rate in steps /4x4
- Drag the graph to adjust ratio and Bias

[SequenceAnim] is to generate repetitive patterns.
You can adjust the steps by dragging with CTRL.
Check out the modes. It's very flexible.

[Counter] is similar to [AnimValue].
It can be useful to drive continuous values like
rotations and phases.

[PerlinNoise] is the go-to algorithm to make things
jiggle in a natural way. Perfect for camera shaking
and so many other things.
Click me

Reactions to audio input or the current project soundtrack is an advanced topic.
It's probably easier to check out one of the tutorial videos for that.

Here's a short example of what you could do with that.
Press play to activate the soundtrack.

Tooll also provides possibilities for keyframe animations.
You can animate any scalar and vector parameter in the parameter window.

Animated operators have a small orange "animation" tag in the corner, 
like this one:

If you click on "Dope" / "Curve" in the Time Control Bar
you can toggle between Dopesheet and Curve mode.
Dragging keyframes holding the Shift-key toggles
snapping.

Another powerful option for procedual animation is [TriggerAnim].
Take a look at the following example:

A different version of effects are triggered if any of the events on the left occur.
Here is a more elaborate example on how to use an animation event...

We create a new clear color for our render target, by cycling through a gradient. 
Notice how [Counter] uses a modulo to repeat the cycle.

Combine two [TriggerAnimation] with [Remap] to 
create a bouncy font size.
Use an integer count to pick a string from a list...
...and pick from a list of meshes to draw.
An interactive tutorial how to render content with Tooll's rendering pipeline.

Tooll is all about drawing (or "rendering") realtime content. 
This playground will give you an introduction.

Here is a typical setup of the basics steps.

For each of these steps there are many operators to achive different effects.
Please check out the [HowToUseOperators] for more details.

Generate and apply environment texture and
show it in the background. The Camera 
has to follow later so the background 
matches the camera movement..
This is an advanced setup that illustrates many components required for a PBR light setup.

Many draw operators allow to set specific drawstyles.
Here are some examples for the results you can achieve 
by adjusting the parameters of [DrawMesh]...

Here is an example for loading and setting up PBR Assets with complex textures.
The awesome "Cerberus" gun is made by Andrew Maximov (see link in description)

Some tips:
- Select and pin the final operator operators on the right to the output window so see the results.
- Enable Idle-Motion on the timeline toolbar, to see some animations.
- hover over the comment-icons to learn more.
... into an image buffer ...

Some "content" like buffers or textures...

You can discover numerous additional Mesh generators in the symbol browser within the lib.3d.mesh.generate namespace.
... it's now drawn...
... with a "setup" ...

... and finally we can apply a post effect.

Please select this operator (and pin it in the output window) to see the result.

Also check the video tutorial for the Raster effect linked in the description of this operator.
Load and distort a mesh...

... we add a displacement effect and animate its phase over time ...

You can Select this operator and press Shift-B to bypass this effect.
Now we draw the mesh.
A bit of colored fog for depth.
Render to an image buffer using anti-aliasing.

Setting the material with a generative texture for the emissive color.

Notice how the pattern highlight color is brighter than 1 so it glows nicely.

Apply post-processing ambient occlusion to darken creases.

Note how we also have to connect the RenderTarget.DepthOutput for this effect to work.
Split vertices for flat shading.
Apply glow to HDR colors in the emissive texture and  environment.
A lense flare setup that follows the point light position.
Some dust particles that wiggle around.
Finally we apply some color grading and vignette.
This is a fancy operator isn't it? If you are curious, you can double click it to look inside and learn how this is made.
Note how we adjust the culling to None so we also render backfacing triangles.
We use the geometry as OBJ (see the link in the description)...

We're using CombineMaterialMaps to create the combined texture.
That's the reason we change the roughness-offset to 0.
Note how we adjusted the Roughness Remap curve to make the gun slightly less shiny.
Normally you draw a single mesh...
...but you can also use a list of Points to draw instances.

Notices how we increased the MultiSampling to 8 samples to reduce some of aliasing on the finer details of the gun.

These samples are ONLY computed at the edges of the geometry, not of the surfaces.

SetEnvironment without a connected connected texture allows us to enable the default background and adjust is brightness.

Also check the documentation fo this operator.
We use this "Null"-object as a reference for the center of our scene, so we don't have to guess the depth of field's focus center.
We also add a rotating point light just for completeness.
We add a point light and animated it.
This is playground that gives an overview about Tooll's main image effects operators.

There are effects that use the incoming 
image to generate patterns or shapes.

Here are examples of effects that
transform or distort an image buffer.

This operator picks one of the incoming effects.

Your can toggle the grid icon in the 
Time Controls to pause this.

Here are some basic image effects.
Also note, that most operators
have presets you can explore.

TIPP: Hold the ALT-Key while
hovering over presets.

Many effects use a second input
as mask or effect input. Here are
some examples.

Blend is the go-to operator to
combine image buffers.

However you should consider using [Layer2d]
for better rendering performance.

This is nice example of 
the kind of effects that
can be achieved with compute
shaders.
[BlendWithMask] uses a mask image to control the blending.

You don't need an effects layer for [DirectionalBlur] .
But it really results in some very interesting visuals.

[Displace] uses the gradient of effect
images to distort images.
Fake Light produces something like an emboss effect.
This is another displacement variation.
Blending
This example gives a playful interactive introduction to Tooll's operators and how they work.

Everything in T3 is made out of operators.
These operators can be structured into the following categories.
Values
Buffers / Data on GPU
Draw instructions
Draw attributes
Flow control
Render Targets
Image Effects

You can quickly distinguish the catories by their respective output type: Float-Number, Buffer, Command, Image, etc.
There are many more types but understanding these foundations will get you far...

Although the data is flowing from left to right, the graph is actually "evaluated" from right to left!

Let's look at the following example.
Please click on the [RenderTarget]...

1. If this RenderTarget
is selected, it "requests"
its input command.

2. This connected operator
sets a camera perspective
and also requests its connected 
command.

3. This operator finally wants
to "draw" something,
but it needs some
content, so, ...

4.  ... finally this operator
provides the actually data
in form of faces and vertices.
This example show that graphs can form complex networks (but not loops).

While the graph is being evaluated (remember: from right to left), parameters
for where and how to draw things are collected.

Transformations like Offset, Scale and Rotation
are accumulated.

Settings for Material, Time and resolution 
are overwritten. The last one (on the left) wins.

Switch and Pick operators both help you to build complex
setups that respond to inputs like time, audio or sensor data.
This interactive tutorial explains how Tooll's [ParticleSystem] works and how you can use it.

There are many forces to pick from. 
Here are some examples.

TIP: Please enable idle motion and select 
the final output to see the effect.
This is a most simple example of a particle system...

A set of point to emit 
(this can be tens of thousands)

One or more forces that are 
applied to the emitted particles.

It generates points that can be used 
for rendering or other effects.
The [SurfaceForce] simulates collision of the primitive sphere, cube or plane.
Emit a single point once per bar.
These points are repelled out of the sphere and then attracted towards it.

The VisualizePoints operator can be used
to show the particle's velocity.

Here are some examples for different emitters with
a very simple [DirectionalForce] as gravity.

Notice how we enable initial velocity for the [ParticleSystem].

Here are some examples how to chosing different methods 
of drawing the particles can lead to a wide variety of results.
A VERY simple particle effect.
A simple fire like effect.

This slightly more advanced example highlights the [StepAxisForce].
On every beat some of the particles are accellerated towards an axis.
Because they leave a [PointTrail] behind, this evalually results into a grid-like structure.

This is a very simple particle force. 
We animate its force with the current time.
Here we only pick a single force. But particle system can be connected to many.
This counter is incremeted once every bar add switches between different forces.
This is also nice.

The [SurfaceForce] can be used an attractor, a container or a reflective surface.
Also see the examples further blow.
Note how we set "SetWTo" to ParticleSpeed. This can then be used by the [VisualizePoints] operator to show can the length of the velocity indicator.
We generate a new buffer with slightly randomized point orientations.
Switch between the different emit points on every bar.
This draws points as billboards with some shading.

Select and pin this operator to see the results.

TIP: Don't forget to start playback or enable Idle motion in the toolbar below.

This operator computes the size of each face to produce a uniform random distribution of of points on the mesh surface.

Notes how these points are oriented with their normal pointing towards to mesh normal.
This converts the point into a GPU buffer.

We randomly rotate the points.
Notice how we change the transformation space to "Point" to rotate around each point's center instead of the object center.
Notice how we set a fixed resolution instead of using the requested output resolution.

Similar to [PointsOnMesh] this generates random points depending on an image's brightness.

This operation is VERY slow for large image resolution. Unless the image is animated the result of this computation is cached though.

We utilize this operator to pick only one of the [LinePoints] for emitting.
The index is incremented every frame.
Simple white points. Notice that the Point's W attribute is used for scaling the points.
We switch between different draw styles once a frame.
We can instantiate meshes at each point.
We can also clone other points at the particles positions.

This op uses a volume with a slow fall-off radius to define the strength of the transformation.
This can lead to very interesting results...

A similar volume with a slow falloff can be used for "selecting" points.
Selection in this case means setting the W-Attribute.

because this is then used by [DrawPoints] it looks like the points are fading out.

We change the orientation of this circle toward the y-axis (pointing up),
and adjust the orientation so Z-points inwards.
We adjust the aging rate and write the particle age to the result points W attribute so it can be used by [DrawBillboards].
We use the W-attribute for sampling a gradient and scale curve for each particle.

We constantly emit this one point in center, leaving to a gradual increase in complexity.

Tip: Try using a [RadialPoint] op instead.

We reduce the particle count to 10k because we draw a line trail for each of those particles.

The current particle speed is written to W so it can be used by [DrawBillboards].

These are very long trails leading to roughly 10 million points connected by particles.

Notice how we also insert seperators if the distance between source points is too large.
We ignore the points with for the lines.

...40% of the particles are accellerated along the x,y, or z-axis.

Notice the y-axis: 
- it's chosen only 5% of the time, but then with 4x the velocity.
On every beat...

Uses draw the W attributes to highlight fast particles.

The Gradient uses HDRD colors, that spread nicely with [Glow].
Everythings looks better with glow.
Visualize the used emits points with their position and index.

We adjusted its parameters to it creats 4 points in a on the Y-axis.

Notices how we also adjusted the OrientationAxis to X and adjusted the orientation angle to adjust the points's z (forward) direction.

We also disable the CloseCircleLine to prevent overlapping points at start and end.
Select and pin operator and don't forget to enable Idle motion in the timeline toolbar.
This playground gives you an introduction on how point buffers can be used to generate content and drive effects.

There are many ways to generate point buffers.
Here is a short selection.
Points can be drawn in many different styles:
Combining and blending

A point is a small structure that combines flexibility 
with a small data size for great rendering performance.
Here is a Point. It has...
A position XYZ:

An orientation:
It has 4 components because
we use quaternions for better
interpolation

And a W-Attribute:
Which is used for various effects like...
- selection
- representing line width
- scale factores
- particle age.

We use this operator to 
upload the buffer to the GPU.
We can use this point's position to draw more points...
...and these positions to draw even more line points at these positions.

...or create another modified copy
and draw mesh instances there...

This helper operator visualizes points
and their orientation.  This one is 
permanently visible. But you can toggle
the default for these gizmos with the 
output window "Gizmo" toggle.
Modifying
Generating Points
Refine points

Most operators will create NEW buffers with manipulated, combined or filtered points.
This allows you to create reproducible  and controllable effects.

The following operators DIRECTLY MODIFY buffers,
like you would expect from a particle simulation.
Here are some more examples for how to use points.

Adjusting parameters with the Parameter Window

1. Select the [Blob]...
2. Notice how the parameter window shows the things you can do with it..

You can...

1. Drag values horizontally to change them.
2. Click a value to type, e.g. values like "2.1" or fomulas like "1.4/3"

4. Click on a color to open the color picker.
5. Drag a color vertically to adjust transparency or brightness.

Convert input parameters to into a buffer

A very simple proportional-integral-derivative controller.

Note that the increment is a rate that get multiplied with the current frame duration: With an increment of 1 you have a full value change of 1 unit after one second.

Generates a repetitive LFO-like signal syned to the current BPM rate. It supports various shapes, modes and forms.

You can manipulate the rate and shape directly in the graph by dragging with CTRL+ left mouse button.

Some tips:
- Please checkout the [HowToAnimate] playground to see some applications.
- You can use [SetSpeedFactors] to override the incoming rate, which is very useful for live VJ setups.

- Also have a look at [AnimVec2], [AnimVec3], and [TriggerAnim].

Generates a repetitive LFO-like signal syned to the current BPM rate. It supports various shapes, modes and forms.

You can manipulate the rate and shape directly in the graph by dragging with CTRL+ left mouse button.

Some tips:
- Please checkout the [HowToAnimate] playground to see some applications.
- You can use [SetSpeedFactors] to override the incoming rate, which is very useful for live VJ setups.

- Also have a look at [AnimValue], [AnimVec3], and [TriggerAnim].

Generates a repetitive LFO-like signal syned to the current BPM rate. It supports various shapes, modes and forms.

A very versatile operator that uses beat time to increment values periodically.

Note that you can adjust many properties directly within the graph while holding CTRL+key.

Keeps the current input value as long as Keep is true.
This can be useful for building interactive features like stop watches.
A helper that combines 3 sin waves into a vector

Generate interactive animation values than can be triggered with a boolean value.
It offers a variety of shapes and modes.

Tips:
- Hold CTRL to directly manipulate rate and shape in the graph.
- Have a look at [HowToAnimate] to get some ideas on how to use this.

An example setup might be:

[HasValueIIncreased]->[TriggerAnim]->[SampeGradient]->[Blob]

Defines a Gradient from a set of Colors and positions.
This can be useful for animating gradients.

Position outside the range of 0 ... 1 will be ignored.
Gets the color of a certain position in the texture

Defines a gradient that can then be sampled into a color or used further by [GradientsToTexture] or other operators.

The first output returns the sampled color.
The second output the gradient structure.

Right click in the parameter window gradient to adjust interpolation mode or save presets.

Blends the connected input images with cross-fading and using a float index.

Please note: this will lead to inconsistent behaviour if used with images of varying resolution unless you set an explicit resolution.

Also see: [PickTexture]
Uses a float index to alpha blend between draw scenes.

Controls how frequently the sub graph is being executed. 
This can be useful for increasing or slowing down simulation speeds.
Executes the subgraph only once. This can be useful for initializing buffers or resetting states.
A helper that first evaluates a command input before returning a texture2d. This can be useful for compute shader processing.

Performs a sequence of drawing operations and then restores the graphics context. You can use it for grouping or activating and deactivating parts of your graphs.

Since [Execute] itself does nothing, you can also use it to name things by inserting it into the graph and setting the instance name by pressing Enter.

An alternative to [Execute] is [Group], which can also have a translation and multiple input connections.

Prints a message to console log. 
This can be useful for debugging updates, caching and timing in complex graph networks.

Executes the sub graph multiple times. This can be very useful for iterating a drawing functions.

You can use [GetFloatVar] and [GetIntVar] to access the iterator variables. 

Please note that this operation creates draw calls for each iteraction and thus is not meant for loop counts exceeding 1000 or more.

Please check the example.

Enables the sub graph on the left side only with the playback time is within the timeclips region allowing you to cut from scene to scene.

This allows you to edit sequences similar to non-linear editing applications with timeclips in the timeline.

Creates Points and Sprites from a text that can be animated and then rendered with [DrawPointSprites] or [DrawPointSpritesShaded].

This operator is an advanced solution that loads a BmFont fond definition and the matching MSDF (multichannel distance field) texture and generates a set of buffers.
This buffers can then be modified and combined with other operators.

The Point - buffer includes position, orientation and W (size).
The Sprite - buffer contains additional attributes for rendering like texture UV coordinates for characters, pivot, size and layout information.

Some tips:
- You might replace the Point buffer with another buffer (e.g. [RadialPoints].
- For rending basic text usage consider using [Text].

Check the examples.

Can be used to define a text string that can be used later.

TIP: To increas the size of the input pannel,  you can right click on the edge of the operator and switch display to "Resizable".

Produces a wide selection of text writer effects that 
can be linked to AudioReactions. Interesting Setups are

[MockStrings]->[GetStringPart]->[ScambleString]

To add line breaks use "\n".

Alternative titles: Concat, Join
Extracts directory, filename and extension from a filepath and checks if filepath exists.
Converts a list of float numbers to String

Converts a float value into a string.

You can use the .net string format descriptor various effects, like...

Here are some examples for for the value 1.2345

{0:P1} -> 123.45%
{0:000.000} -> 001.234
{0:0} -> 1
{0:G3} -> 1.23
need {0:1.2} cookies  -> need 1.2 cookies

Converts an [IntValue] to a string.

Tip: You can override the string formatting to something like... "{0:0} times" add prefexis or suffixes.
Joins the members of a string with with a separator.
A small selection of strings of different categories.
Gets a lines, words or charactsr from the input string. Good for type writer effects, etc.
Picks a string of multiple connected.
Returns a random word per beat.
Looks for an characters or strings in within another string and returns are new string with the matches replaced.
Repeats a string multiple times.
Wraps a string a column width

Draws PBR shaded instances of a mesh defined by the connected point buffer. It uses the current settings for material, point lights, fog and environment. It can use the point's W attribute to control the size of the instances.

Checkout the [HowToDrawThings] on how to set these up.

Also checkout [DrawMesh] and [RepeatMeshAtPoints].
A more abstract shading style
Draws a mesh without any shading.

Uses PBR rendering to draw a mesh using the current settings for material, fog, point lights, transform and camera. For convenience Tooll adds a default reflection and two point lights attached to the camera to a RenderTarget. You can override these by adding [SetEnvironment] and [SetMaterial] operators further up (further right) in your graph.

You can adjust various parameters to achieve wireframe or both sided rendering.

Also take a look at [DrawMeshAtPoints], [DrawMeshUnlit], [DrawMeshHashed] and the [HowToDrawThings] playground.

Tip: This effect can be combined with [SetFog].

This might be useful for debugging or to use as content.
A helper gizmo that can uses a fragment shader to draw smooth grid lines.
Provides a 3d position in world space that can but used to drive other components.
Plots a history curve of a value.

Only executes the subgraph if the set visibility matches the visibility of the evaluation context.

The user can toggle the gizmo visibility by the gizmo icon in the output window.

This helper operator visualizes points and their orientation. It is permanently visible, but you can toggle the default settings for these gizmos using the "Gizmo" toggle in the output window.

Understanding the size, order, and orientation of points in space can be crucial for content creation.

Depending on the use case, this operator can help you visualize:

    The centers
    The "w" attribute (represented by the scale of the center points)
    The "w" attribute (listed as the connected table on the left)
    The orientation with its axes: x (right), y (up), z (forward)
    The orientation as sprites (indicated with an "F")
    The velocity of the points encoded in the rotation (relevant only for Simulation operators).

Also, please take a look at the presets.
Draws additional informations like index or position on points.

An internal wrapped used by the editor output window. 

Should not be used and must not have input parameters.

Please consider using [GridPlane].

Draws mesh normals, tangents and bitangents as lines for analysis. 
This can be useful to verify that TBN space is spatially consitent.

Adds a depth of field effect.

Hint: Use a [Locator] and its DistanceToCamera output to use automatic focus distance.

Sets the image based lighting (IBL) for the current RenderTarget. This texture can then be used by drawing operators for physically based rendering (PBR) further left in the graph.

Some background information: a standard technology for rendering is to use environment textures that store various degrees of roughness in their mip map levels: fully reflective chrome in the highest resolution and very blurry/diffuse reflections in the lower levels. This is not just done be blurring, though: a single ultra bright pixel (E.g. the sun) can brighten the complete diffuse reflection. This computation is very(!) expensive and should not be done in real-time for high resolution environment maps.

To compute this IBL map [SetEnvironment] needs a cube map texture. As of now you can load equirectangular HDR maps only in DDS format and convert them with a [TextureToCubemap]. We are working on making this more convenient. You can also use procedural image textures for this.

NOTICE: For the background environment to have the correctly aligment, the camera must be set after the environment:

[DrawMesh]->[SetMaterial]->[SetPointLight]->[SetEnvironment]->[SetCamera].

Also see: [HowToDrawThings]
Set fog rendering properties for the sub tree.

Sets the phyical base rendering (PBR) material for the current RenderTarget which is then used by [DrawMesh] and other PBR rendering operators. Each of the material properties can be controlled by a color or by connecting a texture input.

Please note that color parameter is multiplied to the texture: so to for an emissive texture to be visible, you have to first set the Emissive Color to one.

The base (albedo) color can also be adjusted by the Draw operators.

For the roughness rendering the draw operators need an IBL texture set by [SetEnviroment] . We uses a default IBL map as a default.

Draws the a point buffer as lines. The lines will be aligned to the camera, but their width will shrink with distance to the camera. You can override this with the ScaleWithDistance parameter. We use the point’s W attribute as a scale factor for the line width. If the W attribute of a point is NaN (Not a Number) that point is not being drawn and acts as a separator between the adjacent line segments. This allow a point buffer to contain multiple disconnected line segments.
DrawLines ignores the orientation defined by the points. Consider using [DrawRibbons] if you need consistent orientation.

Some caveats
---------------
Long line segments that intersect the camera plane (I.e. one point is in front of the camera and the other behind the camera) will not be rendered correctly. Please consider using [DrawRaypoints] for this.

Performance considerations
---------------
Drawing lines is fast. Depending on your graphics card, you can draw millions of lines per frame. Performance will by impacted by the length of your lines rather than point count. This is directly related to your render target’s resolution and multi-sampling level (MSAA).
Similar to [DrawBillboards] this operator draws meshes instead of images.

Note: This operator was previously called "DrawMeshAsSpheres".

Draws a point buffer with the set camera, transform and fog. The points are drawn as camera-facing billboards, ignoring the point orientation. The W attribute of the points is used for scaling. This can be controlled with the UseWForSize parameter.

You can connect a texture to override the round shape.

There are many Operators allowing you to create and manipulate point buffers in countless ways. Please have a look at the examples listed below.

For additional effects you can experiment with different blend modes or disable depth testing. Note however that the points are drawn in the order they are defined in the buffer and not sorted by distance to camera. This can introduce unwanted artifacts with transparent blending.

Although drawing points is fast, drawing very large points can lead to high fill rates and can drastically impact render performance.

Also see: [HowToDrawThings], [HowToUsePoints]

A force for the [ParticleSystem] that applies random accelerations toward an axis direction. This can lead to interesting results in motion design. If ApplyTrigger is true, a random selection ratio of particles is chosen and accelerated.

Use the following options:

- AxisDistribution to control the frequency of XYZ axis selection.
- AddOriginalVelocity to control whether the original acceleration is replaced or mixed in.
- Set Seed to a value greater than 0 to control randomness. If it's set to 0, the current frame number is used as the random seed.

Please note that the RotationAxis space may depend on the [ParticleSystem.OrientTowardsVelocity] parameter. You can also try combining this effect with [ParticleSystem.Damp] for enhanced results.

Note this operators has been deprecated by [ParticleSystem].

Creates a simulation buffer for applying simulation like force fields, curl noise or flocking simulation. It initially creates a copy of the connected source point buffer. You can then reset to this initial state or constantly blend towards this original state. This can be very helpful to "mix in" a valid state and thus keeping a simulation under control.

The mix in factor controls how much of the original state is being restored:

- 0 the simulation runs completely free
- 0.03 a small percentage is constantly mixed into the simulation thus avoid too extreme deviations
- 1 is equivalent of resetting to the source.


For experimental effects you can use mix values exceeding the range between 0 and 1.

also see: [SimulateBoidsExample], [HowToUsePoints]

Implements an optical flow effect that generates a motion vector field, which can be used to drive particle effects.

The effect requires successive image frames as input, which can be generated by using [KeepPreviousFrame].
The motion vectors are stored in the red and green channels of the result. The blue channel is used for the magnitude of the detected motion.

Parameters:

    OutputMethod: Switch between grayscale (neutral values: R 0.5, G 0.5, B 0) or signed (with ranges from -1 to 1).
    Amount: Controls the magnitude of the detected motion.
    Lod: Specifies which MipMap level of the input textures should be sampled. This results in a blurring of the effect.
    ClampRange: Can be used to clamp and normalize the results, preventing values from becoming too small or excessively large.

The shader implements the Lucas-Kanade flow algorithm: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucas%E2%80%93Kanade_method
It builds upon a previous shader implementation by mds2 on Shadertoy: https://www.shadertoy.com/view/XlBcRV"

Generate a set of points that with decreasing to sizes that can be used to draw a Doyle spiral:

In the mathematics of circle packing, a Doyle spiral is a pattern of non-crossing circles in the plane in which each circle is surrounded by a ring of six tangent circles. These patterns contain spiral arms formed by circles linked through opposite points of tangency, with their centers on logarithmic spirals of three different shapes.

Speed factors are multiplied to most animation operators like [AnimValue] and [Counter].

This is an extremely powerful method to adjust the pace of visuals while staying beat synced.

In NormalizedRates mode...
- ...0.5 means neutral (factor 1). 
- ...lower means slower: 1/2 1/4 1/8 1/16 frozen
- ...larger means faster  x2 x4 x8 x16 x32

SpeedFactorA is applied to:
[Counter]

SpeedFactorB is applied to:
[AnimValue]
[AnimVec2]
[AnimVec3]

To keep things flexible it supports Image and Commands types (but not crossing between them).
